title: Impacts of policy change on farm incomes and biodiversity in the uplands: a knowledge transfer project.
abstractText:
This short project builds on a RELU-funded project which developed a series of mathematical models showing the relationships between upland livestock farming and biodiversity - in this case, as measured by the diversity and abundance of moorland birds.

These models were constructed for a case study based in the Peak District. Working with three main stakeholders (Natural England, the Peak District National Park Authority and the National Farmers Union), a series of  "policy briefings" will be produced, which explain in non-technical terms what our models predict about a series of possible changes to agricultural and rural policy in the uplands. These briefings will be made available on the Moors for the Future website.

The predicted impacts range from effects on farm incomes and land use, to changes in moorland birds. These changes include loss of the Single Farm Payment, and the re-design of agri-environmental schemes.

A one-day workshop with a wide range of stakeholders in the Peaks will be arranged to discuss what important research questions remain unanswered on the future of upland farming and its links with biodiversity.
